  "article_text": [
    "fix positive integers @xmath1 .",
    "the commutative cluster algebra @xmath2 is the @xmath3-subalgebra of @xmath4 generated by the _ cluster variables _ @xmath5 , where the @xmath6 are rational functions in @xmath7 and @xmath8 defined recursively by the _ exchange relations _ @xmath9",
    "it is a fundamental result of fomin and zelevinsky @xcite that , although the exchange relations appear to produce rational functions , one always obtains a laurent polynomial whose denominator is simply a monomial in @xmath7 and @xmath8 .",
    "they actually showed the following slightly stronger result .",
    "for any + @xmath10 we have @xmath11 $ ] .",
    "the cluster algebra @xmath2 is of _ finite type _ if the collection of all cluster variables is a finite set .",
    "fomin and zelevinsky @xcite went on to classify cluster algebras of finite type .",
    "the cluster algebra @xmath2 is of finite type if and only if @xmath12 .",
    "the proof of this theorem in particular establishes a connection between denominator vectors of cluster variables and almost positive roots in a root system @xmath13 .",
    "thus we say @xmath2 is of _ affine _ ( resp .",
    "_ wild _ ) _ type _ if @xmath14 ( resp .",
    "@xmath15 ) .",
    "an element @xmath16 $ ] is called _ universally laurent _ since the expansion of @xmath17 in every cluster is laurent .",
    "if the coefficients in the laurent expansion of a nonzero element @xmath17 in each cluster are positive integers , then @xmath17 is called _ universally positive_. a universally positive element in @xmath2 is said to be _",
    "indecomposable _ if it can not be expressed as a sum of two universally positive elements .",
    "sherman and zelevinsky @xcite studied in great detail the collection of indecomposable universally positive elements .",
    "one of their main results is the following : if the commutative cluster algebra @xmath2 is of finite or affine type , then the indecomposable universally positive elements form a @xmath3-basis in @xmath2 , moreover this basis contains the set of all _ cluster monomials _ @xmath18 .",
    "however the situation in the wild - types becomes much more complicated .",
    "in particular , it was shown by lee , li , and zelevinsky @xcite that for @xmath15 the indecomposable universally positive elements of @xmath2 are not linearly independent .",
    "the _ greedy basis _ of @xmath2 introduced by lee , li , and zelevinsky @xcite is a subset of the indecomposable universally positive elements which admits a beautiful combinatorial description . in this section",
    "we will describe a new axiomatic characterization of the greedy basis .",
    "the elements of the greedy basis take on a particular form which is motivated by a well - known pattern in the initial cluster expansion of cluster monomials .",
    "an element @xmath19 is _ pointed _ at @xmath20 if it can be written in the form @xmath21 with @xmath22 and @xmath23 for all @xmath24 .",
    "it is well - known that @xmath25 is the denominator of a cluster monomial if and only if @xmath26 ( cf .",
    "@xcite ) , where @xmath27 is the set of positive imaginary roots , i.e. @xmath28    for @xmath29 , define the region @xmath30 in other words , @xmath31 is the region bounded by the broken line    @xmath32    with the convention that this region includes the closed segments @xmath33 $ ] and @xmath34 $ ] but excludes the rest of the boundary ( see fig .",
    "1 ) .    we can define greedy elements in two different ways , either by axioms or by recurrence relations . here",
    "we choose to define them using recurrence relations as follows .",
    "[ recursive - definition ] for each @xmath35 , there exists a unique element in @xmath36 pointed at @xmath37 whose coefficients @xmath38 satisfy the following recurrence relation : @xmath22 ,    @xmath39 @xmath40_++k-1\\choose k } & \\text { if $ ca_1q\\le ba_2p$;}\\\\            \\sum\\limits_{\\ell=1}^q(-1)^{\\ell-1}e(p , q-\\ell){[a_1-bp]_++\\ell-1\\choose \\ell } & \\text { if $ ca_1q\\ge ba_2p$ , }           \\end{cases}\\]]where we use the standard notation @xmath41_+=\\max(a,0)$ ] .",
    "we define the _ greedy element _ pointed at @xmath37 , denoted @xmath42 $ ] , to be the unique element determined by theorem [ recursive - definition ] .",
    "( 0,3)(.7,.7)(2.5,0)(0,0)(0,3 ) ; ( 0,3)(.7,.7)(2.5,0 ) ; ( 0,0 ) node[anchor = east ] @xmath43 ; ( 2.2,0 ) node[anchor = south west ] @xmath44 ; ( .6,.65 ) node[anchor = south west ] @xmath45 ; ( 0,3 ) node[anchor = east ] @xmath46 ; ( 1.2,0.4 ) node[anchor = east ] @xmath31 ; ( 0,0 ) ",
    "( 3,0 ) node[right ] @xmath47 ; ( 0,0 )  ( 0,3.3 ) node[right ] @xmath48 ;    for @xmath29 , we give a new characterization for the greedy element .",
    "[ three axioms : commutative ] for each @xmath29 , the pointed coefficients @xmath38 of the greedy element @xmath42 $ ] are uniquely determined by the following two axioms :    * ( support ) @xmath49 for @xmath50 ; * ( divisibility ) * * if @xmath51 , then @xmath52 ; * * if @xmath53 , then @xmath54 .",
    "the key step in the proof of theorem  [ three axioms : commutative ] is based on an observation made in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* section 2 ) : the first ( resp .",
    "second ) recurrence relation in theorem  [ recursive - definition ] is equivalent to the vanishing of the @xmath55-th coefficient of the laurent expansion of @xmath56 $ ] with respect to the cluster @xmath57 ( resp .",
    "@xmath58 ) .",
    "it is straightforward to check that such vanishing implies the support and divisibility axioms in theorem  [ three axioms : commutative ] .",
    "the following theorem summarizes the results from @xcite .",
    "[ main theorem - commutative ] ( a ) the greedy elements @xmath56 $ ] for @xmath20 form a @xmath3-basis in @xmath2 , which we refer to as the _ greedy basis_.    \\(b ) the greedy basis is independent of the choice of an initial cluster .",
    "\\(c ) the greedy basis contains all cluster monomials .",
    "\\(d ) greedy elements are universally positive and indecomposable .",
    "our goal in this work is to generalize the above theorem to the setting of rank 2 quantum cluster algebras .",
    "the proof of theorem  [ main theorem - commutative ] given in @xcite uses combinatorial objects called _ compatible pairs _ in an essential way ( cf .",
    "* theorem 1.11 ) ) .",
    "unfortunately this method has difficulties / limitations in generalizing to the study of quantum cluster algebras .",
    "more precisely , if one could simply assign a power of @xmath59 to each compatible pair then the quantum greedy elements would have again been universally positive , which is unfortunately false in general ( see the example at the end of section 3 ) .",
    "this motivates our new approach to theorem  [ main theorem - commutative ] , with the exception of ( d ) , which can easily be generalized to the quantum setting .",
    "in this section we define our main objects of study , namely quantum cluster algebras , and recall important fundamental facts related to these algebras . we restrict attention to rank 2 quantum cluster algebras where we can describe the setup in very concrete terms .",
    "we follow ( as much as possible ) the notation and conventions of @xcite .",
    "consider the following quantum torus @xmath60\\langle x_1^{\\pm1},x_2^{\\pm1 } : x_2 x_1=v^2 x_1 x_2\\rangle\\ ] ] ( this setup is related to the one in @xcite which uses the formal variable @xmath48 instead of @xmath59 by setting @xmath61 ) .",
    "there are many choices for quantizing cluster algebras , to rigidify the situation we require the quantum cluster algebra to be invariant under a certain involution .",
    "the _ bar - involution _ is the @xmath62-linear antiautomorphism of @xmath63 determined by @xmath64 for @xmath65 $ ] and @xmath66 an element which is invariant under the bar - involution is said to be _ bar - invariant_.    let @xmath67 be the skew - field of fractions of @xmath63 .",
    "the _ quantum cluster algebra _",
    "@xmath68 is the @xmath69$]-subalgebra of @xmath67 generated by the _ quantum cluster variables _ @xmath70 defined recursively from the _ quantum exchange relations _ @xmath71    by a simple induction one can easily check the following ( quasi-)commutation relations between neighboring cluster variables @xmath72 in @xmath68 : @xmath73 it then follows that all cluster variables are bar - invariant , therefore @xmath68 is also stable under the bar - involution .",
    "moreover , equation implies that each _ cluster _",
    "@xmath74 generates a quantum torus @xmath75\\langle x_m^{\\pm1},x_{m+1}^{\\pm1 } : x_{m+1 } x_m = v^2 x_m x_{m+1}\\rangle.\\ ] ] it is easy to see that the bar - involution does not depend on the choice of an initial quantum torus @xmath76 .",
    "the appropriate quantum analogues of cluster monomials for @xmath68 are the ( bar - invariant ) _ quantum cluster monomials _ which are certain elements of a quantum torus @xmath76 , more precisely they are @xmath77    the following quantum analogue of the laurent phenomenon was proven by berenstein and zelevinsky @xcite .",
    "[ thm1 ] for any @xmath10 we have @xmath78 .",
    "moreover , @xmath79    a nonzero element of @xmath68 is called _ universally positive _ if it lies in @xmath80[x_m^{\\pm1},x_{m+1}^{\\pm1}]$ ] .",
    "a universally positive element in @xmath68 is _ indecomposable _ if it can not be expressed as a sum of two universally positive elements .",
    "it is known as a very special case of the results of @xcite that cluster monomials are universally positive laurent polynomials .",
    "explicit combinatorial expressions for these positive coefficients can be obtained from the results of @xcite .",
    "this section contains the main result of the paper . here",
    "we introduce the quantum greedy basis and present its nice properties .",
    "analogous to the construction of greedy elements , the elements of the quantum greedy basis take on the following particular form .",
    "an element @xmath81 is said to be _ pointed _ at @xmath20 if it has the form @xmath82 with @xmath22 and @xmath83 $ ] for all @xmath47 and @xmath48 .",
    "the next theorem is an analogue of theorem [ recursive - definition ] , to state our result precisely we need more notation .",
    "let @xmath84 denote a formal invertible variable . for @xmath85",

    "we obtain laurent polynomials in @xmath59 as well .",
    "[ recursive - definition - q ] for each @xmath35 , there exists a unique element in @xmath91 pointed at @xmath37 whose coefficients @xmath38 satisfy the following recurrence relation : @xmath22 ,    @xmath39 @xmath92_++k-1\\brack k}_{v^b } & \\text { if $ ca_1q\\le ba_2p$;}\\\\            \\sum\\limits_{\\ell=1}^q(-1)^{\\ell-1}e(p , q-\\ell){[a_1-bp]_++\\ell-1\\brack \\ell}_{v^c } & \\text { if $ ca_1q\\ge ba_2p$. }           \\end{cases}\\ ] ]    we define the _ quantum greedy element _ pointed at @xmath37 , denoted @xmath93 $ ] , to be the unique element determined by theorem [ recursive - definition - q ] .",
    "the following theorem is analogous to theorem [ three axioms : commutative ] .",
    "[ three axioms : quantum ] for each @xmath29 , the pointed coefficients @xmath38 of @xmath93 $ ] are uniquely determined by the following two axioms :    * ( support ) @xmath49 for @xmath50 ; * ( divisibility ) let @xmath94 denote a formal variable which commutes with @xmath59 .",
    "then * * @xmath95 ; * * @xmath96 .",
    "theorem [ three axioms : quantum ] follows from an argument similar to the proof of theorem [ three axioms : commutative ] .    our main theorem below states that quantum greedy elements possess all the desired properties described in theorem [ main theorem - commutative ] except the positivity ( d ) .",
    "[ main theorem ] ( a ) the quantum greedy elements @xmath97 $ ] for @xmath20 form a @xmath98$]-basis in @xmath68 , which we refer to as the _ quantum greedy basis_.    \\(b ) the quantum greedy basis is bar - invariant and independent of the choice of an initial cluster .",
    "\\(c ) the quantum greedy basis contains all cluster monomials .",
    "\\(d ) if @xmath97 $ ] is universally positive , then it is indecomposable .",
    "\\(e ) the quantum greedy basis specializes to the commutative greedy basis by the substitution @xmath0 .",
    "full proofs of theorems  [ recursive - definition - q ] , [ three axioms : quantum ] and [ main theorem ] will appear elsewhere . the hardest part is to show the existence of quantum greedy elements , i.e. that the recursions in theorem  [ recursive - definition - q ] terminate .",
    "the main idea in the proof is to realize @xmath93 $ ] as a degeneration of certain elements in @xmath68 whose supports are contained in the closure of @xmath99 .",
    "we introduce two variations of quantum greedy elements ( and the three turn out to be identical ) .",
    "let @xmath100 .",
    "define @xmath101 to be @xmath102_++k-1\\brack k}_{v^b } & \\text { if $ ca_1q\\le ba_2p$;}\\\\            \\sum\\limits_{\\ell=1}^q(-1)^{\\ell-1}{\\bar{e}}(p , q-\\ell){[a_1-bp]_++\\ell-1\\brack \\ell}_{v^c } & \\text { if $ ca_1q > ba_2p$ ; }           \\end{cases}\\ ] ]    and define @xmath103 to be @xmath104_++k-1\\brack k}_{v^b } & \\text { if $ ca_1q < ba_2p$;}\\\\            \\sum\\limits_{\\ell=1}^q(-1)^{\\ell-1}{\\underline{e}}(p , q-\\ell){[a_1-bp]_++\\ell-1\\brack \\ell}_{v^c } & \\text { if $ ca_1q\\ge ba_2p$ ; }           \\end{cases}\\ ] ]    for every non - zero pair @xmath105 .",
    "define the upper and lower quasi - greedy elements respectively by @xmath106=\\sum_{(p , q)\\ge0}{\\bar{e}}(p , q ) x^{(-a_1+bp ,- a_2+cq)};\\\\ & { \\underline{x}}[a_1,a_2]=\\sum_{(p , q)\\ge0}{\\underline{e}}(p , q ) x^{(-a_1+bp ,- a_2+cq)}. \\endaligned\\ ] ]    the supports of @xmath107 $ ] and @xmath108 $ ] are easy to compute , and @xmath109 satisfies certain linearity and symmetry properties when @xmath110 , which eventually leads to the conclusion that @xmath107={\\underline{x}}[a_1,a_2]$ ] , hence proves theorem [ three axioms : quantum ] .",
    "theorem [ main theorem ] ( a ) can be proved by a standard argument on the support ; ( b ) follows from the fact that there exist automorphisms @xmath111 and @xmath112 acting on upper and lower quasi - greedy elements as follows : @xmath113)={\\underline{x}}[a_1,c[a_1]_+-a_2],\\\\ & \\sigma_1({\\underline{x}}[a_1,a_2])={\\overline{x}}[a_1,c[a_1]_+-a_2],\\\\ & \\sigma_2({\\overline{x}}[a_1,a_2])={\\underline{x}}[b[a_2]_+-a_1,a_2],\\\\ & \\sigma_2({\\underline{x}}[a_1,a_2])={\\overline{x}}[b[a_2]_+-a_1,a_2 ] ; \\endaligned\\ ] ] ( c ) and ( e ) follow immediately from the definition .",
    "we end this section with an example where positivity of quantum greedy elements fails .",
    "let @xmath114 and consider the pointed coefficient @xmath115 in the laurent expansion of @xmath116 $ ] .",
    "using theorem  [ recursive - definition - q ] , we see that @xmath115 is not in @xmath117 $ ] : @xmath118 further computation shows that the greedy elements @xmath119 $ ] , @xmath120 $ ] , @xmath121 $ ] , @xmath122 $ ] , @xmath123 $ ] , @xmath124 $ ] , @xmath125 $ ] , etc .",
    "are not positive .",
    "similarly , positivity can be seen to fail for certain quantum greedy elements when @xmath126 , @xmath127 , @xmath128 .",
    "the construction of the triangular basis begins with the standard monomial basis . for every @xmath129",
    ", we define the _ standard monomial _ @xmath130 $ ] ( which is denoted @xmath131 in @xcite ) by setting @xmath132 = v^{a_1 a_2 } x_3^{[a_1]_+ } x_1^{[-a_1]_+ } x_2^{[-a_2]_+ } x_0^{[a_2]_+ } \\ .\\ ] ] it is known @xcite that the elements @xmath130 $ ] form a @xmath133$]-basis of @xmath68 .",
    "the importance of this basis comes from its computability , however this basis will not serve in our goals of understanding quantum cluster algebras . indeed , it is easy to see that the standard monomials are not bar - invariant and do not contain all the cluster monomials , moreover they are inherently dependent on the choice of an initial cluster .",
    "these drawbacks provide a motivation to consider the triangular basis ( as defined below ) constructed from the standard monomial basis with a built - in bar - invariance property .    as the name suggests the triangular basis",
    "is defined by a triangularity property relating it to the standard monomial basis . to describe this triangular relationship",
    "we introduce the `` @xmath59-positive '' lattice @xmath134m[a_1,a_2]$ ] where the summation runs over all @xmath135 .",
    "we now define a new basis @xmath136\\,:\\,(a_1,a_2)\\in{\\mathbb{z}}^2\\big\\}$ ] by specifying how it relates to the standard monomial basis :    1 .",
    "( p1 ) each @xmath137 $ ] is bar - invariant .",
    "( p2 ) for each @xmath129 , we have @xmath138 - m[a_1,a_2 ] \\in { \\mathcal{l } } } \\ .\\ ] ]    using the universal acyclicity of rank 2 quantum cluster algebras ,",
    "we apply the following theorem .    the triangular basis does not depend on the choice of initial cluster and it contains all cluster monomials .",
    "similar to the support condition for ( quantum ) greedy elements , we make the following conjecture about the supports of triangular elements .",
    "[ conj : triangular support ] let @xmath29 . for @xmath139 , @xmath140 , the pointed coefficient @xmath38 of @xmath141 in",
    "@xmath137 $ ] is nonzero if and only if @xmath142    [ fig:2 ]    ( 0,3)(.7,.7)(2.5,0)(0,0)(0,3 ) ; ( .69,.73)(0,3 ) ( .73,.69)(2.5,0 ) ; ( 0,0 ) node[anchor = east ] @xmath143 ; ( 2.5,0 ) node[anchor = south ] @xmath144 ; ( .8,.8 ) node[anchor = north east ] @xmath145 ; ( 0,3 ) node[anchor = east ] @xmath146 ; ( 0,0 )  ( 3.5,0 ) node[above ] @xmath47 ; ( 0,0 )  ( 0,3.5 ) node[left ] @xmath48 ; ( 0,0 ) circle ( 1.5pt ) ; ( 0,3 ) circle ( 1.5pt ) ; ( 2.5,0 ) circle ( 1.5pt ) ; ;",
    "in this section we present open problems and conjectures on the triangular basis and quantum greedy basis of a rank 2 quantum cluster algebra .",
    "our aim is to find @xmath69$]-bases of @xmath68 satisfying the properties laid out in the following definition .      1 .",
    "each element of @xmath147 is bar - invariant ; 2 .",
    "@xmath147 is independent of the choice of an initial cluster ; 3 .",
    "@xmath147 contains all cluster monomials ; 4 .",
    "any product of elements from @xmath147 can be expanded as a linear combination of elements of @xmath147 with coefficients in @xmath148 $ ] .",
    "note that all elements in a strongly positive basis are universally positive . indeed , consider multiplying a basis element @xmath149 by a cluster monomial @xmath150 with @xmath151 sufficiently large to clear the denominator in the initial cluster expansion of @xmath145 . by properties ( 3 ) and ( 4 ) of a strongly positive basis",
    "the product @xmath152 is in @xmath148[x_1,x_2]$ ] and thus we see that a strongly positive basis element has non - negative coefficients in its initial cluster expansion .",
    "it then follows that @xmath147 is universally positive because it is independent of the choice of an initial cluster .",
    "kimura and qin @xcite showed the existence of bases for acyclic skew - symmetric quantum cluster algebras ( hence for @xmath68 with @xmath153 ) which satisfy ( 1 ) , ( 3 ) , ( 4 ) . in the rank 2 case ,",
    "their bases are exactly the triangular bases , hence satisfy ( 2 ) as well ( see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* remark 1.8 ) ) .",
    "it is easy to see that property ( 3 ) of strongly positive bases together with conjecture  [ str_pos_pointed ] imply that every element of @xmath147 is pointed .",
    "we note that the conclusion of conjecture  [ str_pos_pointed ] holds for both the quantum greedy basis and the triangular basis .",
    "in contrast to the example at the end of section 3 , we do not observe a failure of positivity when @xmath164 , @xmath165 , @xmath166 , @xmath167 , @xmath168 , @xmath169 .",
    "this provides the motivation for assuming the condition ` @xmath160 or @xmath161 ' in conjecture  [ conj : lower - greedy ] .",
    "next we study the expansion coefficients relating the various bases .",
    "let us begin by introducing notation .",
    "for @xmath171 we define expansion coefficients @xmath172 $ ] as follows : @xmath173&=m[a_1,a_2]+\\sum\\limits_{(a'_1,a'_2)<(a_1,a_2 ) } q^{a_1,a_2}_{a'_1,a'_2}m[a'_1,a'_2];\\\\    \\label{eq : triangular - greedy expansion }    c[a_1,a_2]&=x[a_1,a_2]+\\sum\\limits_{(a'_1,a'_2)<(a_1,a_2 ) } r^{a_1,a_2}_{a'_1,a'_2}x[a'_1,a'_2 ] ,   \\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where we write @xmath174 when @xmath175 and @xmath176 .",
    "we now derive a recursion for the expansion coefficients in equation relating the triangular basis to the quantum greedy basis .",
    "our main ingredients will be the defining properties ( p1 ) and ( p2 ) of the triangular basis . note that since each @xmath97 $ ] is bar - invariant , we have @xmath177 by ( p1 ) .",
    "for @xmath178 $ ] let @xmath179_{\\le0}$ ] denote the non - positive part of @xmath180 , i.e. in @xmath180 we evaluate @xmath181 in all terms for which this makes sense . with this notation , we note that since @xmath182 is bar - invariant , it is determined by @xmath183_{\\le0}$ ] .",
    "this proposition can be proved by reducing equation mod @xmath185 to get @xmath186\\equiv \\big[r^{a_1,a_2}_{a'_1,a'_2}\\big]_{\\le0}m[a_1',a_2']+\\\\ & \\quad\\sum\\limits_{(a_1'',a_2'')<(a_1',a_2 ' ) } \\big[r^{a_1,a_2}_{a'_1,a'_2}q_{a_1'',a_2''}^{a_1',a_2'}\\big]_{\\le0}m[a_1'',a_2'']\\mod{\\mathcal{l}}. \\endaligned\\ ] ] keeping in mind ( p2 ) , we reduce the equality mod @xmath185 and apply equation to arrive at the desired recursion .",
    "most of the ideas toward this work from d.  r. and a.  z. were had during their stay at the mathematical sciences research institute as part of the cluster algebras program .",
    "they would like to thank the msri for their hospitality and support .",
    "research supported in part by nsf grants dms-0901367 ( k.  l. ) and dms-1103813 ( a.  z. ) , and by oakland university urc faculty research fellowship award ( l.  l. ) .",
    "the authors would like to thank f.  qin for valuable dicussions .",
    "they would also like to thank s.  fomin for many constructive suggestions .",
    "k. lee and l. li , on natural maps from strata of quiver grassmannians to ordinary grassmannians , _ noncommutative birational geometry , representations and combinatorics , a.m.s .",
    "contemporary math .",
    "_ , * 592 * ( 2013 ) ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we identify a quantum lift of the greedy basis for rank 2 coefficient - free cluster algebras . </S>",
    "<S> our main result is that our construction does not depend on the choice of initial cluster , that it builds all cluster monomials , and that it produces bar - invariant elements . </S>",
    "<S> we also present several conjectures related to this quantum greedy basis and the triangular basis of berenstein and zelevinsky @xcite .    </S>",
    "<S> luster algebras were introduced by fomin and zelevinsky @xcite as a combinatorial tool for understanding the canonical basis and positivity phenomena in the coordinate ring of an algebraic group . </S>",
    "<S> this was followed by the definition of quantum cluster algebras by berenstein and zelevinsky @xcite as a similar combinatorial tool for understanding canonical bases of quantum groups .    in connection with these foundational goals , </S>",
    "<S> it is important to understand the various bases of cluster algebras and quantum cluster algebras . in this paper </S>",
    "<S> , we confirm the existence of a quantum greedy basis in rank 2 quantum cluster algebras . </S>",
    "<S> it is independent of the choice of an initial cluster , contain all cluster monomials , and specializes at @xmath0 to the greedy basis of a classical rank 2 cluster algebra introduced by lee , li , and zelevinsky @xcite .    </S>",
    "<S> another important basis in an acyclic quantum cluster algebra is the triangular basis of berenstein and zelevinsky @xcite . like triangular bases , </S>",
    "<S> quantum greedy bases can be easily computed . </S>",
    "<S> this enables us to study and compare these bases computationally .    </S>",
    "<S> the structure of the paper is as follows . </S>",
    "<S> section 1 begins with a recollection on rank 2 commutative cluster algebras . </S>",
    "<S> we recall the construction of greedy bases here and in the process we provide a new axiomatic description of the greedy basis . in section 2 we review the definition of rank 2 quantum cluster algebras . in section 3 </S>",
    "<S> we present our main result : the existence of a quantum lift of the greedy basis using the axiomatic description . </S>",
    "<S> section 4 recalls the definition of the triangular basis and section 5 provides an overview of results and open problems on the comparison between various bases of rank 2 quantum cluster algebras . </S>"
  ]
}
